evidence_span: Mechanical joints between Zircaloy and nickel-bearing alloys, mainly the Zircaloy-4/Inconel-600 combination, were exposed to water at 232 and 271°C

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: Accelerated hydriding of the Zircaloy occurred at both temperatures

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: At 232° the dissolved hydrogen level of the water was over ten times that at 271°C

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_041_chunk1

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: Severely hydrided Zircaloy components successfully withstood thermal cycling and mechanical testing

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: alloying Zircaloy-2 cladding with 0.2 weight % nickel by eutectic diffusion bonding resulted in high hydrogen ingress rates on exposure to static, degassed neutral water at 360°C

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: With a hydrogen overpressure of 2 MPa above the water saturation pressure, there was extensive hydriding which resulted in Zircaloy disintegration within three days

evidence_span: The majority of the specimens tested were Zircaloy fasteners consisting of a long Zircaloy-4 stem attached to an Inconel-600 support plate with a Zircaloy-4 nut

evidence_span: Chromium-plated (5 to 10 μm thick) 17-4 PH washers, interposed between Zircaloy-4 medium-diameter blanket nuts and an Inconel-600 plate, were effective in preventing smearing by nickel-bearing alloys during graphiteassisted assembly and subsequent accelerated hydriding of the nuts

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_041_chunk5
evidence_span: Chromium-plated (5 to 10 μm thick) 17-4 PH washers

evidence_span: autoclave testing at both 232 and 271°C

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_041_chunk5
evidence_span: Thin (<2.5 μm thick) chromium plating was insufficient to completely avoid smearing by nickel-bearing alloys, and thus some subsequent accelerated hydriding occurred at 232°C

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_041_chunk5
evidence_span: Thin (<2.5 μm thick) chromium plating

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_041_chunk5
evidence_span: even a thin chromium plated layer reduced by about 75% the severity (area and depth) of accelerated hydriding

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_041_chunk5
evidence_span: Heavily hydrided Zircaloy-4 small-diameter seed fasteners withstood mechanical and thermal cycling tests with no evidence of material spalling, gross cracking, or loosening of the fastener components

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_041_chunk5
evidence_span: hydrogen-permeable windows in small-diameter seed fastener nuts heal at 271°C after relatively short exposure in pressurized water reactor core coolant chemistry

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_041_chunk5
evidence_span: Chromium has been demonstrated to be an effective and practical barrier to hydrogen between Zircaloy and mating nickel-bearing alloys

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_041_chunk5
evidence_span: Metallographic examination of Inconel-smeared single- and double-torqued fasteners hydrided at 271°C indicated that the total hydrogen ingress did not appear to increase with continued autoclave exposure (34 to 136 days)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_041_chunk5
evidence_span: The initial high accelerated hydrogen ingress rate was effectively shut off during exposure at 271°C in about 25 days (Fig. 8)
